habitat_description:
Black-necked Stilts inhabit shallow freshwater and brackish ponds, alkaline lakes, wet meadows, open marshes, flooded fields, and pastures (DeGraaf and Rappole, 1995).  They nests on short, emergent vegetation along margins of salt ponds and shallow inland wetlands with cattails, bulrush and sedges and have a strong tendency to nest on human-made impoundments.  Nests are placed on dikes, islands, or high spots with sparse vegetation and are usually, but not always, surrounded by water.  They forage while wading in shallow water along pond margins, mudflats, and impoundments (Robinson et al. 1999).  

Breeds in limited areas of the Southwestern lowlands and chooses areas with shallow water and adjacent vegetation for feeding (Davis, 1997). Breeds in northern Utah, southern Colorado, eastern New Mexico, Cochise, La Paa, Manicopa, Pima, and Yuma Counties in Arizona (New Mexico Department of Game and Fish). In desert wetlands, particularly in Utah, stilts nest along lake shorelines among scattered patches of vegetation, along barren mudflats or on small vegetation over water (Utah Division of Wildlife Resources, 2003).  Summer resident in Nevada (Alcorn, 1988).  Black-necked Stilts are rare spring and fall migrants in western valleys and on the eastern plains and casual in mountain parks (Andrews and Righter 1992).  They are common transients on ponds, rivers, lakes throughout the Sonoran Desert where they choose areas with shallow water and adjacent vegetation for feeding (Davis 1997). They are transient in riparian and aquatic areas (Alcon 1988).  One of greatest migration concentration in the western U.S. is at Great Salt Lake, Utah.  There is greater use of intermountain areas of the U.S. (Nevada, Utah) than the Great Plains.  

Data collected on the distances between nests and water indicate that nests are infrequently over 50 m from water and are most often within 20 m of water (Robinson et al. 1999).  

Winter habitats used by Black-necked Stilts are rice fields, impoundments, salt marshes, mangrove swamps, and sometimes marine shores (Robinson et al. 1999).  Migrating birds use lake, pond, and marsh shorelines and edges. N. Tarr, 26July2010.
